```{r}
library(fpp2)
library(TTR)
library(readr)
BLSJOBSJ <- read_csv("Desktop/BLSJOBSJ.csv")
newjobs_ts<-ts(BLSJOBSJ$`Total Jobs (private and government)`,start=c(2007,01),frequency = 12)
head(newjobs_ts)
plot(newjobs_ts)
stl_plot<-stl(newjobs_ts,s.window = "periodic")
plot(stl_plot)
attributes(stl_plot)
seasadj(stl_plot)
plot(newjobs_ts)
lines(col="red",seasadj(stl_plot))
stl_forecast<-forecast(stl_plot)
plot(stl_forecast)
stl_forecast<-forecast(stl_plot, h=5)
plot(stl_forecast)
decompose(newjobs_ts)
plot(decompose(newjobs_ts))
attributes(decompose(newjobs_ts))
seasadj(decompose(newjobs_ts))
plot(seasadj(decompose(newjobs_ts)))
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
